places.name: Lake Trasimeno
places.description: A lake in Perugia, Italy.

places.name: Perugia
places.description: Perugia is the capital city of Umbria in central Italy, crossed by the River Tiber, and of the province of Perugia.

places.name: Apennines
places.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Sabina
places.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

places.name: Tiber River
places.description: The Tiber River is the third longest river in Italy. Rome is located on its banks.

places.name: Clitunno River
places.description: The Clitunno is a river in Umbria, Italy.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

places.name: New Holland
places.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: Prometheus
persons.description: In Greek mythology, defied the Olympian gods by stealing fire and giving it to humans.

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: Theophrastus
persons.description: A Greek philosopher and the successor to Aristotle in the Peripatetic school.

persons.name: Herodotus
persons.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

persons.name: Plutarch
persons.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

persons.name: Archimedes
persons.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

places.name: Bay of Naples
places.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

places.name: Mount Somma
places.description: A mountain located in the Province of Naples, in the Campania region of southern Italy. It has a collapsed caldera of an older volcano, with Mount Vesuvius rising up from the center.

persons.name: JohnDalton
persons.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: Democritus
persons.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: Anglesey
places.description: Anglesey is an island, and county, on the north-west coast of Wales.

persons.name: Jeremias BenjaminRichter
persons.description: German chemist who worked on the idea of definite proportions.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

places.name: London
places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

places.name: Monmouthshire
places.description: Monmouthshire is a county in south east Wales.

places.name: London
places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

persons.name: JamesWatt
persons.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

places.name: London
places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

persons.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
persons.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: ThomasPoole
persons.description: Tanner based in Nether Stowey, philanthropist and essayist; a friend of Davy and Coleridge.

places.name: Ljubljana
places.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

works.name: Consolations in Travel, or the Last Days of Philosopher
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Postojna
places.description: a town in the traditional region of Inner Carniola, in southwestern Slovenia

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

places.name: Solfatara Caldera
places.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

places.name: Carniola
places.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

places.name: Tivoli, Lazio
places.description: Tivoli is a town north east of Rome and known for the waterfall on the Aniene River.

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

places.name: Sicily
places.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Arabian Peninsula
places.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

persons.name: AdairCrawford
persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: River Danube
places.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

places.name: Drava River
places.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

places.name: Styria
places.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

places.name: Carinthia
places.description: Carinthia is the southernmost Austrian State.

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

places.name: Sava River
places.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Illyrian Alps
places.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

places.name: Carniola
places.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

places.name: Cheshire
places.description: A county in north-western England. The county town is Chester.

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: Alexander III
persons.description: The Great, King of Macedon, from which he conquered much of the world known in Greek antiquity.

persons.name: JuliusCaesar
persons.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Pisa
places.description: Pisa is a city in Italy's Tuscany region best known for its iconic Leaning Tower.

places.name: Lizard Point
places.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

persons.name: Philalethes
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: Ambrosio
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: Edward CharlesHoward
persons.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Ambrosio
persons.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

places.name: The Colosseum
places.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

places.name: Geneva
places.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

persons.name: Marc-AugustePictet
persons.description: Genevan natural philosopher and journal editor. Corresponded with Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

persons.name: JohnDavy
persons.description: Humphry Davy's brother, born in Penzance. Spent some time working with Davy in the Royal Institution before studying medicine at Edinburgh University. Appointed an Army physician he was elevated to the rank of Inspector General of Army Hospitals in the West Indies. Following his brother's death, Davy's notebooks came into his possession which he used in writing biographical studies that strongly defended his reputation. FRSL.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

works.name: Salmonia: or Days of Fly Fishing. In a Series of Conversations.
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

works.name: Salmonia: or Days of Fly Fishing. In a Series of Conversations.
works.author: Humphry Davy

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).
